question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Crews does a great job engaging the class, calling on people to ensure that we are actively translating. He makes it so that everyone gets to participate every day and we always feel comfortable asking questions.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Dr. Crews would guide the class through a Latin work each day, calling on different people to read a few sentences each from the passage. I thought that this class structure was good at getting students to prepare ahead of time. It also encouraged students to understand the grammar of the passages, as Dr. Crews would occasionally interject to point out various constructions, something that helped me remember different Latin grammatical forms.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Prof. Crews method of having each person translate a line is effective since there is no punishment for messing up a portion of your line. By reading and translating before the class, there is a team element as well which is nice.

response_text: I have had the honor of taking three semesters of Latin with Professor Crews. question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Each day Dr. Karsten would have us read a new text, and would always have such extensive knowledge on it as to teach us things the textbook never could. question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This course is a great way to expand your knowledge of Latin texts after having a baseline education in Latin grammar and structure. You will read a variety of classical authors, ranging from Ovid to Livy to Cicero and even Medieval Latin and Vulgate, and be well-versed in the most essential Latin texts after taking this course.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: A good way to fulfil your FL credit while also getting a CZ. The expectations for the course are clear and if you consistently dedicate time to this class you will be able to succeed.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This class is defintely challenging and difficult. However, it is rewardign to look back and see how much you've learned. I feel like it's easy to take classes at Duke where you don't truly retain the information, but this class almost forces you to learn cumulatively.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text:
Professor Woods was very encouraging in offering translation advice but also let us figure out material at our own -- I think she struck a good balance that got the highest effort and engagement from the students. 
I liked the group presentations as well because it got you to engage beyond the routine of reading and translation-heavy style of traditional Latin courses. 
Also, final project engaging with an actual text is very cool, makes the Latin feel real.

Reading new scripts
Medieval book culture - in general, thinking about how we get the texts that we have and how they might reflect each stage of the transmission process

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a variety of scripts that I knew nothing about before this course started, I learned about the history of manuscript and book production, and I learned about how to engage with and create manuscript descriptions and transcriptions of texts. All of these skills have prepared me to better engage with Latin texts beyond critical editions.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Practical hands on work.paired with great readings and class discussion

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: The course was an excellent introduction to a topic I had previously covered only tangentially in the areas of philology, epigraphy, and medieval history and literature. Apart from the new knowledge in the area of paleography, the course was very helpful in beginning to develop the skills to be able to interact with and study material culture. The hands-on component of the exercises and peer review activities was a great exercise in developing focus and working together.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Regular transcriptions and descriptions would be a good component to keep. I also appreciated students being assigned to review each other's transcriptions.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The structure of assignments for each week was very clear and the use of the modules function on Canvas was really helpful in guiding me through the material for each week in a constructive way. I really enjoyed the formal transcription and description exercises and thought that they culminated in the final project well. I liked the mix of contextual readings and hands-on practice with manuscripts each week.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Everything about this class was great and expertly done - the sudent presentations mixed things up, the time was managed well.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: As I specified earlier, hands-on practice in transcription and description was an important component of learning and developing new skills. Another element that enriched the course were the readings concerning different aspects of paleography, from cultural contexts to histories of exemplary individuals, which allowed learning and discussion through different perspectives.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The way Dr. Woods engaged us combined with fascinating material, and just.the way she shared her expertise with us. It was exactly because Duke offers opportunities like this that I came here

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The organization of the course and the class environment encouraged participation by all and the reprocessing of knowledge learned. Starting to produce transcripts and descriptions was challenging but also rewarding and refreshing.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I would absolutely recommend this course. I learned a lot, it was incredibly enjoyable, and Prof. Woods is a wonderful instructor.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: College students are so used to handling books that it is not surprising that they take them for granted. Paleography is a great way to learn how concretely such an important tool for learning came into being and has come down to us preserving for centuries and centuries texts that we can read today with a simple google search. Confronting the somewhat alien materiality and its challenges can be useful and humbling for Classics students but also for any other student.
